_. CHARGE OF SETTING FIRE TO A HOUSE,
Av the Thames Rolice- -court,’ Charles Mawzi was

| At a quarter to four o' ‘clock that “morning Lilly,

| when he met the prisover,.and he said, “I have just

he sid. , 1 have, just comefrom a fire ; IN show you
where it is,” On reaching No. 2, which is an
unoccupied house, prisoner ‘pulled open the ‘shutters
and said, Can't you hearthe fire now?" and Lilly
then heard the crackling of wood. He spring his
yattle, and William Gadd, sergeant, 23 B,. and, ‘Mfred

on opening the back parlour doot he found tho stair-
case in flames; algo'the ground and baseiment floor
partly burnt, ‘Lilly ran for the turmcock, end in the
meantime Sergeant Gadd and Ford, assisted by 2 men
with» hose in the Commercial Bieiver ry, Next ddor to
the house, commended playing on the fire. In. ten
minutes’ time a fire engine arrived, ani the flames
Were extinguished: Sergeant Gadd gave the prisoner
into custody. The prisoner said he went to pit out
the fire, He was’ remanded, one surety in £20°being
